summary: A Washington Post article from August 26, 2019, reporting that investigators found some surveillance footage outside Jeffrey Epstein's cell unusable, raising further questions about the circumstances of his death by suicide at the Metropolitan Correctional Center on August 10, 2019. The article details failures in jail protocols, the medical examiner's ruling, and ongoing investigations by the FBI and DOJ Inspector General.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The financier charged with sexually abusing dozens of young girls, found dead by hanging in his jail cell on August 10, 2019. His death was ruled a suicide.

persons.name: Carol D. Leonnig
persons.context: Co-author of the Washington Post article reporting on the investigation into Epstein's death and the unusable surveillance footage.

persons.name: Matt Zapotosky
persons.context: Co-author of the Washington Post article reporting on the investigation into Epstein's death and the unusable surveillance footage.

persons.name: Barbara Sampson
persons.context: Ruled Epstein's cause of death a suicide on August 16, 2019, following an autopsy.

connections.description: Sampson, as the Chief Medical Examiner, conducted the autopsy and officially ruled Epstein's death a suicide, a conclusion Epstein's lawyers questioned.

events.title: Epstein arrested and charged
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was charged in early July with sexually abusing dozens of young girls in the early 2000s and ordered held without bond.

events.title: Previous incident in Epstein's cell
events.description: Epstein was found on the floor of his cell with marks on his neck. Authorities suspected a suicide attempt; Epstein claimed he was attacked.

events.title: Epstein found dead in cell
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found hanging in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center. He was taken to a hospital and pronounced dead.

events.title: Medical examiner rules death a suicide
events.description: New York Chief Medical Examiner Barbara Sampson ruled Epstein's cause of death a suicide.

events.title: Epstein's 2008 plea deal
events.description: Epstein received a plea deal to resolve similar sex abuse allegations, pleading guilty to two state charges and serving 13 months in jail with work release.

locations: Metropolitan Correctional Center (Bureau of Prisons facility in downtown Manhattan)
keyFacts: Investigators found at least one camera in the hallway outside Epstein's cell had unusable footage, though other clearer footage was captured.
Epstein was found dead by hanging on August 10, 2019, and the death was officially ruled a suicide by the medical examiner on August 16.
The autopsy found fractures in Epstein's neck bones, including the hyoid bone, which can occur in hanging but is also typical in homicidal strangulation.
Jail protocols were violated: Epstein was not checked every 30 minutes as required, he was left without a roommate despite orders, and staff logs may have been falsified.
Epstein's lawyers publicly questioned the suicide ruling and the investigation's thoroughness, stating their intent to conduct an independent investigation.
